<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Expenses Associated with Evaluation of Strategic
    Alternatives:</I>&#160;&#160;On March&#160;28, 2008 the Company
    received an unsolicited proposal from CHLP, which is controlled
    by an affiliate of Vector Capital, the holder of approximately
    69% of our outstanding common shares. CHLP had proposed to make
    an offer to acquire all of our outstanding common shares not
    currently held by CHLP at a price of US$11.00 cash per share.
    CHLP indicated that any such offer would be conditional upon,
    among other things, satisfactory confirmatory due diligence and
    our existing credit facility remaining in place following the
    consummation of any transaction.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Board of Directors of the Company formed a Special Committee
    of the Board, which assisted it in evaluating and responding to
    the CHLP proposal. In addition, the Special Committee undertook
    a process to evaluate other strategic alternatives to maximize
    value for all shareholders. On August&#160;18, 2008, CHLP
    withdrew its proposal and the Board disbanded the Special
    Committee. However, we continued to evaluate other strategic
    alternatives through the month of October, at which point
    negotiations with a third party were
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    46
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    concluded with no transaction completed. The costs of the
    Special Committee and the evaluation of strategic alternatives
    were largely related to professional consulting services.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Interest (Income) Expense, Net.</I>&#160;&#160;Net interest
    expense decreased by $2.0&#160;million in fiscal 2008 from
    $16.3&#160;million in fiscal 2007. The decrease is due to the
    fact we did not use our credit line facility during this fiscal
    period and the increase in our gain on our unhedged interest
    swaps by $399,000 in fiscal 2008. During fiscal 2007, our credit
    line facility was drawn by as much as $43.0&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Amortization of Deferred Financing Fees.</I>&#160;&#160;The
    amortization of deferred financing fees remained the same for
    our fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2008 as compared to our
    fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2007. There has been no new
    credit facilities entered into during the year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Other non-operating expense (income):</I>&#160;&#160;Other
    non-operating expenses, which are generally comprised of foreign
    exchange gains and losses, increased by $2.6&#160;million from
    income of $0.8&#160;million to an expense $1.8&#160;million
    largely as a result of additional unfavorable foreign currency
    exchange losses throughout fiscal 2008. We were adversely
    affected by the strengthening of the US&#160;Dollar versus the
    Euro on our cash and account receivable balances denominated in
    Euros. Our losses on foreign currency exchange increased by
    $3.6&#160;million from gains of $862,000 to a loss of
    $2.7&#160;million in fiscal 2008. The foreign currency
    translation losses are offset by a gain on sale of a long-term
    of investment of $822,000 which was earned in fiscal 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Income Tax Expense (Recovery).</I>&#160;&#160;An income tax
    recovery of $136,000 was recognized for our fiscal year ended
    November&#160;30, 2008 consisting of current tax expense of
    $4.4&#160;million and deferred tax recovery of $4.5&#160;million
    compared to a tax expense of $3.4&#160;million for our fiscal
    year ended November&#160;30, 2007 that included current tax
    expense of $3.5&#160;million and a deferred tax recovery of
    $83,000.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The current tax provision relates mostly to foreign withholding
    taxes which are not creditable due to loss carryforwards.
    Management concluded that it is not more likely than not that
    the resulting foreign tax credits can be utilized. The current
    tax expense increased due to increased tax withholdings on
    Japanese OEM sales in that region. The current tax provision was
    offset by a deferred tax recovery, associated with the reduction
    of the valuation allowance against post-acquisition tax losses
    of InterVideo following the approval of a plan to realize these
    assets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At the beginning of the third quarter of fiscal 2007, we
    received a notice of reassessment from the Ministry of Revenue
    of Ontario (the &#147;Ministry&#148;) for CDN$13.4&#160;million.
    The Ministry reassessment disallows various deductions claimed
    on our tax returns for the 2000, 2001 and 2002 taxation years
    resulting in a potential disallowance of loss carryforwards and
    liabilities for tax and interest. In September 2007, we received
    further notice that the Ministry had applied tax losses and
    other attributes, which reduced the assessment from
    CDN$13.4&#160;million to CDN$6.4&#160;million. Subsequently, in
    November 2007, we received another notice of assessment
    regarding this issue, which increased the capital tax and
    interest owing for the 2000, 2001, and 2002 taxation years. This
    assessment was for CDN$7.5&#160;million. We intend to vigorously
    defend against the assessment. While management believes that we
    have adequately provided for potential assessments, it is
    possible that an adverse outcome may lead to a deficiency in
    recorded income tax expense and may adversely affect liquidity.
    However, we believe that the positions taken in our tax returns
    are correct and believe the potential loss from the assessment
    will not have a material impact on our financial condition or
    results of operations. As of November&#160;30, 2008, no amounts
    have been accrued.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Comparison
    of Fiscal Year Ended November&#160;30, 2007 to Fiscal Year Ended
    November 30, 2006</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our consolidated financial statements for our fiscal year ended
    November&#160;30, 2007 have been prepared in accordance with
    U.S.&#160;generally accepted accounting principles.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;12, 2006, we acquired all of the outstanding
    shares of InterVideo. Accordingly, because the financial
    information for the year ended November&#160;30, 2006 does not
    include InterVideo operations, they are not directly comparable
    to the consolidated financial information presented for the year
    ended November&#160;30, 2007. In the analysis, &#147;Corel
    products&#148; refers to the revenues and expenses related to
    the products which were owned by Corel prior to the acquisition
    of InterVideo.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    47
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total revenues for the year ended November&#160;30, 2007
    increased by 41.4% to $250.5&#160;million from
    $177.2&#160;million for the year ended November&#160;30, 2006.
    Of this increase, $73.0&#160;million was attributable to
    additional revenues generated from InterVideo products. There
    was an increase in total revenues from Corel products of
    $0.3&#160;million in the current year. This increase was driven
    by growth of approximately $16.0&#160;million, in <I>WinZip,
    CorelDraw, iGrafx, </I>and <I>Corel Painter. </I>These increases
    were largely offset by a decrease in <I>WordPerfect</I> revenues
    of $12.1&#160;million and <I>Digital Imaging </I>revenues of
    $3.6&#160;million from last year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Product revenues for the year ended November&#160;30, 2007
    increased by 45.1% to $228.3&#160;million from
    $157.3&#160;million for the year ended November&#160;30, 2006.
    Product revenues for Corel products decreased by
    $2.0&#160;million or 1.3% to $155.3&#160;million for the year
    ended November&#160;30, 2007. This decline primarily reflects
    the decline in sales of <I>WordPerfect </I>and the decrease in
    sales of <I>Digital Imaging </I>products<I>, </I>which was
    partially offset by an increase in the sales of the rest of the
    portfolio of products, led by growth in <I>WinZip, CorelDRAW,
    iGrafx</I> and <I>Corel Painter </I>revenues. The decline in
    <I>WordPerfect </I>revenues for the year ended November&#160;30,
    2007 is due primarily to a decrease in point of sale royalties
    from one of our largest OEM customers, a decrease in enterprise
    license revenue and the latter part of the product lifecycle
    given the launch of <I>WordPerfect Office X3 </I>in the first
    quarter of the prior year. The decline in <I>Digital Imaging
    </I>revenue for the year ended November&#160;30, 2007 are
    primarily attributable to lower POS and APOS (after Point of
    Sale) revenue for <I>Snapfire</I> at one of our largest OEM
    customers, a decrease in the level of upgrades from earlier
    versions of <I>Paint Shop Pro Photo </I>to <I>Paint Shop Pro
    Photo X1 </I>and the repositioning of this brand as our higher
    end product relative to our acquired <I>Photo Impact </I>and
    <I>Photo Express </I>brands. A new version of <I>Paint Shop Pro
    Photo</I> was released in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2007,
    partially offsetting the decrease in sales for fiscal 2007.
    Revenues from our <I>WinZip </I>products increased due to new
    license sales and upgrades resulting from increased conversion
    of trial customers to license users through more aggressive
    in-product messaging. The increase in <I>iGrafx </I>revenues was
    attributable to significant new customer wins in the Japanese
    market, the overall competitiveness of our product portfolio and
    additional marketing and promotional initiatives undertaken in
    the current year. The increase in <I>CorelDRAW </I>revenues
    during the year ended November&#160;30, 2007 was attributable to
    growth in the European market due to significant enterprise
    license agreements and additional promotion and marketing
    activity. <I>CorelDRAW </I>continued to experience growth in
    emerging markets such as Latin America. The increase in <I>Corel
    Painter </I>revenue during fiscal 2007 was due to continued
    worldwide growth in OEMs,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">e-Stores</FONT>
    sales, and channel sales.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Maintenance and services revenues increased by 11.7% to
    $22.2&#160;million for the year ended November&#160;30, 2007.
    This increase was largely attributable to increased sales of
    WinZip&#146;s maintenance program. As a percentage of total
    revenue, maintenance and services revenue declined to 8.9% in
    fiscal 2007 from 11.2%, as a result of the change in product mix
    due to the acquisition of InterVideo. The InterVideo family of
    products generates minimal amounts of maintenance and services
    revenue.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    49
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

    Revenues by Product Group</FONT></I></B>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Graphics and Productivity revenues increased by
    $4.0&#160;million or 2.9% to $141.7&#160;million in fiscal 2007
    from $137.7&#160;million in fiscal 2006. There was a decline of
    $12.0&#160;million in the sales of <I>WordPerfect Office</I>.
    The rest of the Graphics and Productivity portfolio of products
    increased by $16.0&#160;million or 15.5% as compared to the year
    ending November&#160;30, 2006. This was primarily driven by
    growth in <I>WinZip, CorelDRAW, iGrafx </I>and <I>Corel Painter
    </I>revenues. Revenues from our <I>WinZip </I>products have
    grown due to increased new license sales and upgrades resulting
    from increased conversion of trial customers to license users
    through more aggressive in-product messaging. The increase in
    <I>iGrafx</I> revenues was attributable to additional marketing
    and promotional initiatives undertaken in the current quarter,
    and new licensing deals in Japan. The increase in <I>CorelDRAW
    </I>is due to new licensing deals reached in EMEA. The increase
    in <I>Corel Painter </I>was due to continued worldwide growth in
    OEMs,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">e-Stores</FONT>
    sales, and channel sales. The decline in <I>WordPerfect
    </I>revenues was due primarily to the decrease in point of sale
    royalties from one of our largest OEM customers, the decrease in
    enterprise license revenue, and the launch of <I>WordPerfect
    Office X3 </I>in the first quarter of the prior year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Digital Media revenues increased by 175.8% to
    $108.8&#160;million in fiscal 2007 from $39.5&#160;million in
    fiscal 2006. The significant increase was due to the inclusion
    of $73.0&#160;million of revenue in fiscal 2007 that resulted
    from products acquired with our acquisition of InterVideo on
    December&#160;12, 2006. Excluding acquired Digital Media
    products, Corel&#146;s <I>Digital Imaging </I>products decreased
    by 9.2% to $35.9&#160;million in fiscal 2007, as compared to
    $39.5&#160;million in fiscal 2006. The decrease in revenues was
    the result of lower conversion rates and lower point of sales
    and after point of sales (APOS) revenue at our largest OEM
    customer. Some of this decline was offset by the introduction of
    <I>MediaOne, </I>which was not sold in fiscal 2006, as we
    continued to acquire new OEM partners and started to realize the
    benefit of APOS revenue. Also, during the second half of the
    year, we continued to reposition <I>Paint Shop Pro Photo </I>as
    the high end, high value product in a portfolio of Digital Media
    products, which now also includes <I>Photo Impact </I>and
    <I>MediaOne.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Total
    Revenues by Region</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Revenues in the Americas increased by 20.6% to
    $126.0&#160;million in fiscal 2007 compared to
    $104.4&#160;million in fiscal 2006. The increase was principally
    driven by the revenues associated with our new <I>InterVideo
    </I>products, which generated sales of $28.7&#160;million for
    the year ending November&#160;30, 2007. Revenues for Corel
    products declined by 6.9% in fiscal 2007, due to lower
    <I>WordPerfect </I>and <I>Digital Imaging </I>revenues.
    <I>WordPerfect </I>decreased due to the decrease in point of
    sale royalties from one of our largest OEM customers, the
    decrease in enterprise license revenue, and the launch of
    <I>WordPerfect Office X3</I> in the first quarter of the prior
    year. The decline in <I>Digital Imaging </I>revenues for fiscal
    2007 was primarily attributable to lower POS revenue at one of
    our largest OEM customers and the repositioning of the
    <I>Digital Imaging </I>product as our higher end
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    50
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    product relative to our acquired <I>Photo Impact </I>brand and
    <I>MediaOne. </I>A new version of <I>Paint Shop Pro Photo
    </I>was released in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Revenues in EMEA increased by 25.2% to $72.9&#160;million in
    fiscal 2007 from $58.3&#160;million in fiscal 2006. The main
    reason for the increase was the revenues generated by our
    <I>InterVideo </I>products which totaled $10.3&#160;million in
    fiscal 2007. Revenues from Corel products increased by 7.6%
    primarily due to increases in <I>CorelDRAW Graphics Suite
    </I>and <I>WinZip </I>product sales, which offset decreases in
    sales in <I>WordPerfect </I>and <I>Digital Imaging
    </I>product<I>. CorelDRAW Graphics Suite</I> revenues increased
    in EMEA due to continued advances made in the retail and
    enterprise market and the strengthening of the Euro relative to
    the US&#160;Dollar.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    APAC revenues increased by 255.9% to $51.6&#160;million in
    fiscal 2007. The increase was due largely to sales from
    <I>InterVideo </I>products of $34.0&#160;million in fiscal 2007.
    Revenue growth in Corel products was 21.2% for the year ended
    November&#160;30, 2007, due to revenue growth in <I>WinZip
    </I>and <I>iGrafx. iGrafx </I>growth was larger in this region
    due to licensing deals reached with one of our distribution
    partners initiated in the second quarter of fiscal 2007.
    Revenues from our <I>WinZip </I>products have grown
    significantly due to increased new license sales and upgrades
    resulting from increased conversion of trial customers to
    license users through more aggressive in-product messaging.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Cost
    of Revenues</FONT></I></B>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Cost of Product Revenues.</I>&#160;&#160;Cost of product
    revenues increased by 133.6% to $49.8&#160;million in fiscal
    2007 from $21.3&#160;million in fiscal 2006. As a percentage of
    product revenues, cost of product revenues increased to 21.8%
    from 13.6%, for the year ended November&#160;30, 2007. The
    increase in the period was largely attributable to the change in
    our product mix caused by the acquisition of InterVideo.
    InterVideo products generally have higher royalty content then
    Corel products.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Cost of Maintenance and Services
    Revenues.</I>&#160;&#160;Cost of maintenance and services
    revenues decreased to 3.6% of related revenues in fiscal 2007
    compared to 5.7% in fiscal 2006. The increase in maintenance
    revenues was primarily attributable to <I>WinZip&#146;s
    </I>higher maintenance revenues, for which we have experienced
    limited incremental costs to provide.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Amortization of Intangible
    Assets.</I>&#160;&#160;Amortization of intangible assets
    increased by $11.7&#160;million to $26.1&#160;million in the
    year ended November&#160;30, 2007, from $14.4&#160;million in
    the year ended November&#160;30, 2006. This increase was due to
    the $15.5&#160;million of amortization related to the intangible
    assets of $86.6&#160;million acquired with InterVideo.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    51
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Operating
    Expenses</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During the first quarter of fiscal 2008, we re-classified some
    of our fiscal 2007 operating expenses related to our Information
    Technology group, so that costs of certain employees were better
    aligned with the functions they performed. As a result, for the
    year ended November&#160;30, 2007, we have reduced our general
    and administrative costs by $2.7&#160;million, increased our
    sales and marketing costs by $976,000, increased our research
    and development costs by $1.7&#160;million, and increased our
    cost of products sold by $71,000.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->

    <TD width="5%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=lead -->
    <TD width="5%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=lead -->
    <TD width="6%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=hang1 -->

    <B>November&#160;30,</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Percentage<BR>
    </B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Sales and Marketing.</I>&#160;&#160;Sales and marketing
    expenses increased by 30.5% to $71.6&#160;million in fiscal 2007
    as compared to $54.9&#160;million in fiscal 2006. For the year,
    sales and marketing expenses as a percentage of revenue
    decreased to 28.6%, as compared to 31.0% for the prior period.
    The increase in sales and marketing expenses was as a result of
    additional costs associated with assuming InterVideo operations.
    The decline in expenses as a percentage of revenue from the
    prior year was due to our integration activities which have
    created cost synergies in the current period.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Research and Development.</I>&#160;&#160;Research and
    development expenses increased by 79.1% to $46.4&#160;million
    for the year ended November&#160;30, 2007, as compared to
    $25.9&#160;million for the year ended November&#160;30, 2006. As
    a percentage of total revenues, research and development
    expenses increased to 18.5% from 14.6% in fiscal 2007 as
    compared to fiscal 2006. The increase in research and
    development expenses was as a result of products acquired from
    InterVideo which are part of our Digital Media group of
    products. Further research and development investment is made in
    Digital Media due to relative maturity and growth potential of
    this sector.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>General and Administrative.</I>&#160;&#160;General and
    administration expenses increased to $34.4&#160;million in the
    year ended November&#160;30, 2007, from $24.3&#160;million for
    the year ended November&#160;30, 2006. As a percentage of total
    revenues, general and administration expenses remained the same
    at 13.7% as compared to fiscal 2006. The increase in general and
    administration costs was due largely to the integration of
    InterVideo operations and resources as well as additional
    expenses incurred to be compliant with Sarbanes-Oxley.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Acquired in-process Research and
    Development.</I>&#160;&#160;Intangible assets acquired with
    InterVideo included $7.8&#160;million of in-process research and
    development projects that, on the date of the acquisition, the
    related technology had not reached technological feasibility and
    did not have an alternate future use. As required by purchase
    accounting, this in-process research and development was
    expensed upon acquisition in the first quarter of fiscal 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>InterVideo Integration Expense:</I>&#160;&#160;Integration
    costs relating to the acquisition of InterVideo totaling
    $5.2&#160;million have been recorded during the year ending
    November&#160;30, 2007. These costs relate to the integration of
    the InterVideo business into our existing operations, including
    travel costs, retention bonuses, incremental employees engaged
    solely for integration activities, other incremental costs for
    our employees who worked on the integration planning process,
    consultants for integrating systems, and other one-time charges
    for integrating systems.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    52
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Restructuring.</I>&#160;&#160;In the fourth quarter of fiscal
    2007, our management initiated a restructuring plan to
    centralize much of our Digital Media operations in Greater China
    and Fremont, California. Additionally, further changes have been
    made to staff to align and balance our global teams. This
    resulted in the planned closure of our Minneapolis location in
    fiscal 2008 as well as the termination of certain individuals.
    The total amount of the liabilities arising from this plan are
    estimated to be $2.2&#160;million, of which $1.9&#160;million
    relates to termination and related benefits, and
    $0.3&#160;million relates to the closure of our Minneapolis
    facility. These charges were funded by our cash flow from
    operations. We expensed restructuring charges of
    $1.4&#160;million in fiscal 2007 as a result of this plan.
    Further expenses of $0.5&#160;million were recorded in fiscal
    2008. We expect significant reductions in employee expenses in
    future periods as a result of the restructuring plan, however,
    some employees have been added in other locations to replace
    some of the individuals terminated.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For our fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2006, restructuring
    costs of $810,000 represent severance costs related to the
    realignment of our sales and marketing force in the Americas and
    reductions in our research and development team.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Non-Operating
    (Income) Expense</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

    Other non-operating (income) expenses

</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>

    (565
</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Loss on Debt Retirement.</I>&#160;&#160;We incurred a loss on
    debt retirement of $8.3&#160;million in fiscal 2006 relating to
    the write-off of deferred financing costs as a result of our
    refinancing $130.0&#160;million of credit facilities prior to
    maturity, as part of our initial public offering on May&#160;2,
    2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Interest (Income) Expense, Net.</I>&#160;&#160;Net interest
    expense increased by $4.9&#160;million in fiscal 2007 from
    $11.3&#160;million in fiscal 2006. The increase was due to the
    additional long-term debt of $70.0&#160;million incurred as a
    result of our acquisition of InterVideo.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Amortization of Deferred Financing Fees.</I>&#160;&#160;The
    amortization of deferred financing fees decreased to
    $1.1&#160;million for our fiscal year ended November&#160;30,
    2007 as compared to $1.2&#160;million for our fiscal year ended
    November&#160;30, 2006 as a result of the lower financing fees
    incurred under the senior credit facility entered into during
    our fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2006, as compared to
    those incurred with the Credit Suisse First Boston
    (&#147;CSFB&#148;) facility entered into during our fiscal year
    ended November&#160;30, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Other non-operating income:</I>&#160;&#160;Other
    non-operating income, which is generally comprised of foreign
    exchange gains and losses, increased from $0.6&#160;million to
    $0.8&#160;million largely as a result of additional favorable
    foreign currency exchange gains in fiscal 2007 relating to the
    weakening of the US&#160;Dollar versus the Canadian Dollar and
    the Euro. Our gains on foreign currency exchange increased by
    $0.5&#160;million from $0.4&#160;million to $0.9&#160;million in
    fiscal 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Income Tax Expense.</I>&#160;&#160;Income tax expense of
    $3.4&#160;million for our fiscal year ended November&#160;30,
    2007 consisted of current tax expense of $3.5&#160;million and
    deferred tax recovery of $83,000 compared to a tax expense of
    $4.7&#160;million for our fiscal year ended November&#160;30,
    2006 that included current tax expense of $3.4&#160;million and
    a deferred tax expense of $1.3&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Current taxes for the years ending November&#160;30, 2006 and
    2007 included foreign withholding taxes plus taxes incurred by
    our foreign subsidiaries. Deferred taxes in fiscal 2007 relates
    to an additional $5.0&#160;million valuation allowance against
    all deferred tax assets assumed in the InterVideo acquisition.
    In the third quarter, we determined that it was no longer more
    likely than not that the deferred tax assets would be realized,
    and
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    53
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    accordingly a valuation allowance was recorded. This was offset
    by a reduction in our deferred income tax liability related to
    the amortization of intangible assets recorded on the
    acquisition of InterVideo. Deferred taxes in fiscal 2006 related
    to the tax benefits realized in Canada from the use of tax loss
    carryforwards, existing prior to our acquisition by Vector
    Capital, in post-acquisition periods, less deferred tax credits
    relating to WinZip operations in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We had current tax expense of $3.4&#160;million on a loss before
    tax of $9.6&#160;million due mostly to foreign withholding taxes
    which are not creditable due to the Canadian loss carryforwards
    and foreign taxes in jurisdictions which are profitable.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">LIQUIDITY
    AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of November&#160;30, 2008, our principal sources of liquidity
    include cash and cash equivalents of $50.3&#160;million and
    trade accounts receivable of $33.2&#160;million. We also have a
    five-year $75.0&#160;million revolving line of credit facility,
    of which $69.4&#160;million is unused as of November&#160;30,
    2008.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At November&#160;30, 2008, approximately 68% of our cash and
    cash equivalents are held on deposit with banks and the
    remaining amount of approximately 32% is held in commercial
    paper. The largest proportion of our bank deposits is held in
    Canadian banking institutions which we believe to be secure in
    the current global economy due to historically tighter
    regulations. We believe that we will be able to access the
    remaining balance of bank deposits outside of Canada as these
    deposits are with large reputable banks. We have and will
    continue to make a series of short-term investments in term
    deposits and commercial paper. Our investment policy is to
    invest in low risk short-term investments which are highly
    graded commercial paper and term deposits. We have not had a
    history of any defaults on this commercial paper, nor do we
    expect any in the future given the grade and short term to
    maturity of these investments. All commercial paper on hand at
    November&#160;30, 2008 have been repaid, and subsequently
    reinvested.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As we enter fiscal 2009, based on our current business plan,
    internal forecasts and the risks that are present in the current
    global economy, we believe that cash generated from operations
    and the accessible portion of our operating line of credit
    facility included under our senior credit facility, will be
    sufficient to meet our working capital and operating cash
    requirements for the next fiscal year. Cash from operations
    could be affected by various risks and uncertainties, including,
    but not limited to, the risks detailed in or incorporated by
    reference in Item&#160;1A&#160;&#151; <I>&#147;Risk
    Factors&#148;</I>.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In fiscal 2008, the Company generated an increase in cash of
    $25.6&#160;million, largely driven by our operating cash flows,
    increasing our cash and cash equivalents to $50.3&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In fiscal 2009, our financing payments will increase and our
    operating cash flows could decrease, as we will incur a few
    significant one time payments, and there is uncertainty
    associated with revenues in this current economic environment.
    The one time payments include a cash sweep payment due under our
    senior credit facility in February 2009 which is estimated to be
    $17.5&#160;million, and a payment made to settle a long-time
    contingency with a supplier in the estimated amount of
    $2.0&#160;million. These items will be partially offset by a
    reduction in our operating expenditures, an elimination of
    salary increases for fiscal 2009, a reduction in restructuring
    payments, a reduction in one-time expenditures such as the
    charges associated with the evaluation of strategic
    alternatives, and a reduction in our capital expenditures. If we
    compare our fourth quarter of fiscal 2008 total expenses for
    sales and marketing, research and development and general and
    administrative versus that of the fourth quarter of fiscal 2007,
    we have achieved cost savings of $4.4&#160;million over the
    quarter, which is largely due to the completion of our
    restructuring activities and foreign exchange. We expect similar
    decreases due to restructuring activities for the first three
    quarters of fiscal 2009. We also have no significant liabilities
    for our defined pension benefit plan, our past restructuring
    activities, and do not expect significant cash flows from tax
    uncertainties, and in particular our tax contingency with the
    province of Ontario.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We expect that our actions to reduce operating expenses will
    allow us to generate operating cash flows sufficient to sustain
    operations, to address the one time items above, and to offset,
    in whole or in part, the potential impact of a decrease in
    future revenues. Despite the weakening economy in the fourth
    quarter of fiscal 2008, we generated operating cash flows of
    $16.0&#160;million, of which only $5.8&#160;million was
    attributable to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    54
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    a change in our operating assets and liabilities. These
    operating cash flows were higher then what we generated in the
    prior quarters of fiscal 2008. We also believe the global
    positioning of our diverse group of products will reduce the
    adversity that we face created by the uncertainty in the present
    economy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Management believes that if the need arises we will be able to
    obtain funds through our line of credit, based on our evaluation
    of the status of our lender as secure. While it is unlikely that
    we will be able to draw down the full line of credit of
    $75.0&#160;million due to debt covenants, we believe we are in a
    position to make draws of approximately $40.0&#160;million based
    on our current financial position at November&#160;30, 2008,
    without violating our current debt covenants. The available line
    of credit could be used to facilitate the acquisition of other
    companies or existing technologies. Ultimately, we would need to
    obtain approval from our lenders for permitted transactions as
    defined in the credit agreement. Given the recent failures of
    some financial institutions there is no guarantee that funds
    will be made available to us under our line of credit. Refer to
    risk factors, in item&#160;1A of this
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-K,</FONT>
    <I>&#147;We are potentially exposed to default risk on our
    interest rate swaps and our line of credit&#148;.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Management believes that, despite the current economy, it is has
    the liquidity barring any unforeseen circumstances, to continue
    to operate through fiscal 2009 and pursue its planned business
    objectives.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Based on our current senior debt facility, a significant balloon
    payment will be required in fiscal 2012. We expect that we will
    maintain our creditworthiness over this time such that this
    payment can be refinanced at or prior to that date.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Working
    Capital</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The net working capital deficit at November&#160;30, 2008 was
    $6.3&#160;million, a decrease of $8.9&#160;million from the
    November&#160;30, 2007&#160;net working capital deficit of
    $15.2&#160;million. The decreased working capital deficiency is
    primarily due to the additional operating cash flows we have
    generated, which is offset by the additional current liability
    of $17.5&#160;million pertaining to an estimated cash sweep
    payment.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Current assets at November&#160;30, 2008 were
    $94.5&#160;million, an increase of $23.0&#160;million from the
    November&#160;30, 2007&#160;year end balance of
    $71.5&#160;million. The change is due to an increase in our cash
    and cash equivalents of $25.6&#160;million and an increase in
    deferred tax assets of $3.1&#160;million, which is partially
    offset by a decrease in accounts receivable of
    $5.1&#160;million. The increase in our cash position was
    attributable to our continued generation of operating cash
    flows, while being able to minimize our financing activities,
    primarily our debt principal payments. The increase in the
    deferred tax assets is due to our assessment that it is more
    likely then not that we will realize the benefits of certain
    Taiwanese tax attributes after the re-organization of the
    ownership of our digital media intellectual property. The
    decrease in the trade accounts receivable balance is due to the
    timing of cash receipts from some of our largest customers.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Current liabilities at November&#160;30, 2008 were
    $100.8&#160;million, an increase of $14.1&#160;million from
    November&#160;30, 2007. The increase primarily resulted from the
    increase in the current portion of the long-term debt of
    $16.8&#160;million which has increased due to our first cash
    sweep payment of approximately $17.5&#160;million which is due
    in February 2009. This is partially offset by our decrease in
    payroll and profit sharing accruals and a decrease in our trade
    accounts payable.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Cash
    Flows</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TD align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 10pt">
    Cash provided by (used in) investing activities
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    (1,906
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    )
</TD>

&nbsp;
</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Year
    ended November&#160;30, 2008 compared to year ended
    November&#160;30, 2007.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cash flow from operations of $35.5&#160;million in our fiscal
    year ended November&#160;30, 2008 was an increase of
    $9.0&#160;million from our fiscal year ended November&#160;30,
    2007. The increase in operating cash flows in fiscal
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    55
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    2008 as compared to fiscal 2007 is attributable to the timing of
    cash receipts from large OEM customers, and to the fact that in
    fiscal 2007 we had assumed and reduced a working capital
    deficiency in the acquisition of InterVideo. There were no
    significant non-operating cash receipts included in net income
    in our fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cash flow used by financing activities was $3.1&#160;million in
    our fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2008, a decrease of
    $74.9&#160;million compared to cash provided by financing
    activities of $71.8&#160;million in our fiscal year ended
    November&#160;30, 2007. This decrease is largely due to an
    additional term loan of $70.0&#160;million which was obtained in
    conjunction with the acquisition of InterVideo, and a decrease
    in cash generated from exercised options of $5.1&#160;million
    due to terminated InterVideo employees in the prior year. In the
    upcoming periods, payments made to reduce debt will increase due
    to cash sweep obligations within our term loan agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cash used in investing activities was $6.6&#160;million in our
    fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2008, a decrease of
    $118.2&#160;million compared to $124.8&#160;million in our
    fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2007. The additional cash
    outlay reflects the purchase of InterVideo on December&#160;12,
    2006 and the remaining interest in Ulead on December&#160;28,
    2006 totaling $120.9&#160;million. This was offset by the
    additional purchases of long lived assets of $3.2&#160;million
    of which the majority related to computer hardware, to meet our
    plan to invest in our infrastructure.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At the beginning of the third quarter of fiscal 2007, we
    received a notice of reassessment from the Ministry of Revenue
    of Ontario (the &#147;Ministry&#148;) for CDN$13.4&#160;million.
    The Ministry&#146;s reassessment disallows various deductions
    claimed on our tax returns for the 2000, 2001 and 2002 taxation
    years resulting in a potential disallowance of loss
    carryforwards and liabilities for tax and interest. In
    September, 2007, we received further notice that the Ministry
    had applied tax losses and other attributes which reduced the
    assessment from CDN$13.4&#160;million to CDN$6.4&#160;million.
    Subsequently, in November 2007, we received another notice of
    reassessment which increased the capital tax and interest for
    the 2000, 2001 and 2002 tax years The reassessed balance changed
    to CDN $7.5&#160;million. We intend to vigorously defend against
    the reassessment. While management believes that they have
    adequately provided for potential assessments, it is possible
    that an adverse outcome may lead to a deficiency in its recorded
    income tax expense and may adversely affect its liquidity.
    However, we believe that the positions taken in our tax returns
    are correct and estimate the potential loss from the
    reassessment will not have a material impact on our financial
    condition or results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Indebtedness</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On May&#160;2, 2006, we entered into a $165.0&#160;million
    senior credit facility consisting of a $90.0&#160;million term
    loan with a six-year maturity and a $75.0&#160;million revolving
    line of credit with a five-year term. Proceeds from this
    refinancing were used to repay our existing debt at that time.
    On December&#160;12, 2006, this facility was amended and we
    completed our acquisition of InterVideo and Ulead. The
    acquisition was partially financed through an amendment to the
    credit facility for an additional $70.0&#160;million of term
    loan borrowings. In addition there was a $43.0&#160;million draw
    on our revolving line of credit and the remainder was financed
    from cash of the combined company. During the year ended
    November&#160;30, 2007 we repaid the $43.0&#160;million
    revolving line of credit. There was $69.4&#160;million
    outstanding on the line of credit as of November&#160;30, 2008,
    as we have drawn $5.6&#160;million relating to a letter of
    credit.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The credit facility agreement requires us to make fixed
    quarterly principal repayments of 0.25% of the original
    principal amount on the term loan, or $225,000 from June 2006 to
    December 2006 and $400,000 from January 2007 through to December
    2011, with the balance of the loan due in April 2012. The term
    loan and revolving line of credit bear interest at floating
    rates tied to either the Alternate Base Rate (&#147;ABR&#148;),
    which equals the higher of (i)&#160;the federal funds rate plus
    50&#160;basis points, and (ii)&#160;the prime rate plus 2.25%
    until December 2006 and ABR plus 3.00% thereafter, or Adjusted
    LIBOR plus 3.25% until December 2006 and Adjusted LIBOR plus
    4.00% thereafter. On an annual basis, beginning the first
    quarter of fiscal 2008, we may be required to make a cash sweep
    payment to fund our principal balance, based on excess cash flow
    as defined in the agreement. No payments were made or were
    required to be made through November&#160;30, 2008. We currently
    estimate that a $17.5&#160;million payment will be required for
    the fiscal 2008 cash sweep, which is required to be made in the
    first quarter of fiscal 2009.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    56
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the above loans, the facility also provides us
    with a $25.0&#160;million letter of credit and a
    $5.0&#160;million Swingline commitment. The applicable interest
    rate on any borrowings is based on a leverage ratio pricing
    grid. As at November&#160;30, 2008, there was $5.6&#160;million
    outstanding for a letter of credit. No balance was outstanding
    on the Swingline commitment.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the senior credit facility, we obtained
    interest rate protection by entering into an interest rate swap
    with its principal lender for $134.5&#160;million. The variable
    rate of interest is based on one-month LIBOR plus 4.00% for
    $90.0&#160;million of the interest rate swaps and three-month
    LIBOR plus 4.00% for $44.5&#160;million of the interest rate
    swaps. The fixed rates range from 8.19% to 9.49%. Currently, our
    exposure to default risk on our interest rate swap agreements is
    minimal as we are in a liability position on all interest rate
    swaps.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The borrowings under the senior credit facility are
    collateralized by a pledge of all our assets, including
    subsidiary stock. Under the terms of the credit agreement we are
    subject to restrictive covenants, such as restrictions on
    additional borrowing, distributions and business
    acquisitions/divestitures. It also includes the following
    financial covenants:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>

    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    <B>&#149;&#160;</B>
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    a maximum total leverage ratio, which is defined as the ratio of
    total debt to trailing four quarter consolidated Adjusted
    EBITDA, as defined in the credit agreement, to be less than
    specified amounts over the term of the facility as follows:
</TD>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The future debt payments on long-term debt as of
    November&#160;30, 2008, including the annual cash sweep for
    fiscal 2008 as discussed above, are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <TD width="69%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->

</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">
    <B>Principal</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">
    <B>Interest</B>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of November&#160;30, 2008, we were in compliance with all
    debt covenants. Management continues to monitor compliance with
    debt covenants carefully, and at this point believes
    that&#160;&#151; barring further worsening of the current global
    economic difficulties beyond our current projections&#160;&#151;
    we will continue to be in compliance with debt covenants
    throughout fiscal 2009. We have included the following
    reconciliation from the cash flow provided by operations to the
    Adjusted EBITDA used in the covenant calculations. Adjusted
    EBITDA is a non-GAAP measure that we use to assist in evaluation
    of our liquidity and is used by our bank
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    57
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    lenders to calculate compliance with certain financial
    covenants. Adjusted EBITDA was $60.9&#160;million for our fiscal
    year ended November&#160;30, 2008 compared to $57.3&#160;million
    for our fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    This measure does not have any standardized meaning prescribed
    by GAAP and therefore is unlikely to be comparable to the
    calculation of similar measures used by other companies, and
    should not be viewed as alternatives to measures of financial
    performance or changes in cash flows calculated in accordance
    with GAAP. We consider cash flow from operations to be the
    closest GAAP measure to Adjusted EBITDA. For our fiscal years
    ended November&#160;30, 2008, 2007 and 2006, we had cash flow
    from operations of $35.5&#160;million, $26.5&#160;million and
    $36.2&#160;million, respectively. The table below reconciles
    Adjusted EBITDA to cash flow from operations:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Contractual
    Obligations and Commitments</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We have operating leases for office space. In accordance with
    GAAP, neither the lease liabilities nor the underlying assets
    are carried on the balance sheet as the terms of the leases do
    not meet the criteria for capitalization. Payments on these
    leases were approximately $5.9&#160;million for our fiscal year
    ended November&#160;30, 2008, $6.8&#160;million for our fiscal
    year ended November&#160;30, 2007 and $5.2&#160;million for our
    fiscal year ended November&#160;30, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We have debt as discussed in the indebtedness section above.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table outlines our contractual commitments over
    the next five years and thereafter at November&#160;30, 2008:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
